abstracts.cdata!:
The outcome of the Industrial
            Development Project for Nepal was marginally satisfactory.
            The project achieved its main objective, its impact on
            institutional development was modest, sustainability is
            uncertain at this time, and both the Bank and Borrower
            performed satisfactorily. Several lessons can be learned
            from this project. First, investment lending projects in
            countries with less developed financial and industrial
            sectors should be kept simple with a limited number of
            components. Second, credit lines through DFIs for
            encouraging industrial investments should avoid putting in
            micro-management conditionalities, as they may violate
            normal banking instincts and principles. Third, implementing
            DFIs should be allowed to charge market rates of interest
            where a competitive lending environment exists. Lastly,
            foreign equity participation with management assistance for
            DFIs in developing countries should be encouraged.

Nepal - Industrial Development Project :
            Credit 1535 - Project Agreement - Conformed

Nepal - Industrial Development
            Project : Credit 1535 - Project Agreement - Conformed

docna.cdata!:
Nepal - Industrial Development Project :
            Credit 1535 - Credit Agreement - Conformed

display_title.display_title:
Nepal - Industrial Development
            Project : Credit 1535 - Credit Agreement - Conformed

abstracts.cdata!:
The Industrial Development Project is
            part of IDA's continuing efforts in assisting the
            Government to promote industries in Nepal with greater
            private sector participation.  Project components include:
            (a) a line of credit to NIDC to finance industrial
            investment projects; and (b) technical assistance and
            training to NIDC in strengthening operational standards and
            procedures particularly in project implementation, project
            supervision and management information.  There is also a
            project component involving; (c) consultancy and advisory
            services to improve formulation and implementation of
            industrial and export incentives, tourism promotion, and
            efficiency and quality of leather goods production and to
            assist in formulating a development program for the light
            engineering subsector.  Finally, the project provides; (d)
            foreign exchange funds to establish an Import/Export
            Facility for export oriented enterprises.  The project does
            not contain any unusual risk.
